content: Yeah you're considering the right things I'd encourage to just keep examining what you are already and see where it takes you.

What you are describing is how conventional self-improvement operates, in that yes, if for example you have social anxiety, it is possible to "improve" your social anxiety by practicing your social skills, having multiple real life experiences of positive results, and then your social anxiety will diminish. The reason this actually occurs is because you now perceive a lower threat in social interaction that before, and so experienced less psychological fear (anxiety). This is because your beliefs about yourself have changed. 

What I am suggesting is that below this structure there can be permanent resolution through understanding that the perceived danger to ourselves in the first place is not actually understood nor real. It can all end through examination, and the gradual process of self-improvement and belief modification is not the only means.

Not exactly sure what you meant in the first part, but the way our anxiety is perceived is that we have had traumatic experiences in the past that have shaped our present experience, but what is literally occurring is our present memory has caused us to have certain beliefs about ourselves that caused the emotion. It is important to see that it is not past trauma, but present belief that shapes our experience in order to be able to resolve that.

It is partially the case if I get what you're saying. If someone has a phobia of spiders, then it is partially a natural fear of immediate danger when seeing a spider, probably greater than the average person, and then also an immense psychological fear that is layered on top of that. Same sort of thing with the fear of the deep sea or something like that. 

It's similar to public speaking, in that going on stage in front of 100 people and disappointing them is actually a natural experience of shame/guilt and necessary. It tells you not to do that again as people communicated you have basically not given them anything of value and worsened their experience, but the psychological anxiety around performance and judgment is entirely unnecessary and formed by our self-image.

To clarify, I’m not sure if it was a typo or miscommunication, but I’m saying there is no belief and no emotion, not that there is a lack of one and a lingering other. They both stop instantly and never reoccur. It is analogous to being in fear your actions will sent you to hell. You can try to consciously improve your behaviour, but the emotion and behaviour dissolves entirely when there is a realization that you invented hell and it isn’t real

There is always a more deeply rooted subjective belief if there is social anxiety, otherwise you wouldn’t know to call it social anxiety because you wouldn’t know what it related to. You don’t need to know “exactly” what it’s connected to because in truth it isn’t connected to anything other than a vague fear of people and their judgment or treatment of you and what that would do to affect your beliefs about yourself, but it is important to at least try to probe into to become that the fear is at its root actually circular and a fear of your thoughts about yourself, not an actual danger.
You can make an intelligent judgment, but there is no emotional or stress response unless there is a perception of physical endangerment.

@gamenightguy The thoughts don't go away and then the emotion dissipates over time, they both instantly end as they're both linked by belief structures about what you think is occurring and the emotional response of anxiety is towards that perception.

I'd like to clarify that when you immediately perceive a physical threat like a person coming towards you with a knife, the fear experienced is not in relationship to "oh man I might get hurt in like 2 seconds, which is technically the future so not real just my imagination", no, it is happening now and you are responding to that event. We are getting way too bogged down in "what technically constitutes the specific quantity of measured time to qualify as the future or past" when it's completely unnecessary. If you want a more practical corollary, you can say "would a duck be scared by this or not". If the answer is yes, then it is physically dangerous, if it isn't, then it's probably anxiety and related to an individual beliefs. 

Both physical fear and anxiety are learned with regard to what objects you are fearful of, in that a baby isn't necessarily afraid of heights or bears, but uses their intelligence to associate concepts of danger with physical pain. Genuine fear is associated with that. This is one structure and it only activates in response to immediate perception of physical danger. It *can* be related to thought, it just so rarely happens that there is a situation that is physically dangerous *and* requires thought to realize it's dangerous that it basically only comes up when people on here invent a hypothetical. A duck would be scared of a bear if it saw it, and so would you. If a duck were kidnapped and suddenly woke up in a dark room, it would just be confused. Humans are intelligent enough that we can respond to thought being applied to immediate scenario to realize we are in a dangerous unfamiliar location and fear would respond to thought in this scenario. In 99.999% of real life scenarios any fear response to thought or dreams is anxiety and related to beliefs and our self-image.

Anxiety is completely different from genuine fear because it isn't associated with the fear of objects that appear in our present environment, but with the fear of objects that appear in our imagination. It *is* subjectively perceived to be the same as being in a room with a bear. But instead of being scared of bears, you are scared of other people and whatever subjective characteristic about them you believe there is threat to you in. This will occur automatically in the way you have described because social anxiety itself is a response to the belief that social interaction poses a danger to us. It is natural to want to object to that by saying "well, here's *why* it IS dangerous" and that is already the whole point. If you believe there is danger in social interaction you will be frightened by whatever element in particular you think is threatening to your self-image and who you think you are. If for example you think it is a problem if people don't like you, then you will be frightened to interact with people you don't know because you don't want them to express displeasure in talking to you. If you think it is a problem if a girl/guy doesn't like you, then you are going to be mortified waiting for them to text back. The "Pavlovian response" is not a sort of background hum that is conditioned, it is an immediate and very intelligent response to a deeply perceived threat to your imagination of yourself. The moment that self-image or belief collapses it will no longer occur.

Good to read your comments after you posted this, hopefully some good insights.

1. You respond to a bear mauling you to death in the same way you respond to looking over or getting close to a dangerous cliff. It is not "imagining you are getting mauled to death" or "imagining you are falling through the air" it is an automatic response to sight, sound and sometimes thought being applied to immediate sensory experience. It isn't lying in bed, perfectly safe, and then getting anxious when you imagine something that might go wrong in your life, it literally "I am right now literally in a physically dangerous scenario". 

2. You're misunderstanding what I mean when I'm saying there is no past and future, in that what you are describing is *not* the future. What you are calling the future (but isn't) is the present thought "I am going to be hungry later" that has semantic meaning and leads to action, but is just an idea you have right now. There is no "future" in it. Then you presently drive to the store, then you presently buy the groceries, then you presently cook the food and eat it. There is no experience of the past or future in any of this. What I'm pointing to is that there is absolutely no experience of the past or future, yet we call "eating dinner later" the future despite it not being the case, it is again just some words you are thinking right now. There is no experience of anything ever at any time other than present experience. This isn't a "well technically" argument, it is immensely important because we psychologically believe "buying groceries later" *is the future* which creates a parallel problem in our life that doesn't exist. If you only ever respond to present experience, it will resolve all "future" problems, but by reacting to present experience and an invented "future" we distort our behaviour by reacting to two "realities" simultaneously. 

3. This is the same thing: "How much weight I can bench press" is just knowledge that you have, it isn't any different than "How much can the other guy bench press". The difference is if someone insults "my" bench press it hurts our feelings, but if they insult someone else's bench press we don't care. It is the identification with "this knowledge is about *me*" that falsley creates attachment and emotional response. They are both just thoughts in our mind created from sensory experience and aren't different. It's like if I were to write "15x15" on a piece of paper and someone said "225", then you said "oh, that's my bench press!" and someone else is like "no, it's math problem". The reality is it's the number 225 being mistaken for "self-knowledge" that symbolizes a characteristic about ourself when it really is an identification we have mistaken for ourselves.
